We have a passion in this country, deep, wide and apparently boundless, for putting people in jail. We are a punishment first society, rather than an opportunity first one. Prisons are even celebrated by the right as bringing much needed jobs to small towns and rural areas (and no one thinks it is pathetic to do so?).

The forces of change are strong, but the forces of resistance, and ingrained habit, are very, very difficult to move. That is one reason that societies need occasional revolutionary levels of change: it moves the dialog to another zone, sweeping old habits off the page.

We have a law enforcement industry and a lot of people put bacon on their table and cars in their garages by playing their small role in arresting, prosecuting, evaluating, jailing, moving around, feeding and guarding prisoners, among other functions. All of those people will resist moderation in the legal system, not because they are evil, but because the money in their pockets will blind them to the negative results of so many people in prisons for long terms.

Prisons help to make a permanent class of the unemployable, of outcasts, while the families they leave outside the walls suffer from poverty and disrupted family life. No one measures the total costs of these destructive measures.

The BLS employment data systematically overstates employment and economic health. Household survey respondents are categorized as employed if they spend as little as one hour per week working in their own trade or business, no matter or not if that business is economically viable. Part-time workers are counted as employed in the U3 headline employment number. And it is my understanding that those who have been unemployed for longer than a year are simply not included in the survey.

It's high time to recalibrate the BLS survey to more meaningfully measure unemployment and underemployment. Until then, the U6 measure of unemployment and underemployment (13.8%) remains a better measure of the health of American workers. Keep a sharp eye, too, on the number of Americans "leaving" the workforce.

@ Katie:
"Do you think an algorithm could recognize the sarcasm in that paragraph? " Yes, I do, and much more besides.

What I don't understand is all the negativity expressed in these comments. What is this smugness seeping in from the edges, these assertions of "human superiority" beyond the reach of any algorithm? Do they in fact mask an insecurity, a mounting sense that ground formerly held secure may be slipping away?

If the hypothesis that humans are inherently superior is correct, why should it not be subject to testing, to proof? I say, let the developments in AI and related fields run their course and take us wherever they may lead. We may find that our values and vanities are not so transcendent after all, that there is a great deal we can learn from machines.
